title: Brigatinib: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Brigatinib: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**What is Brigatinib?**

Brigatinib is a medication used to treat a certain type of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) that has spread to other parts of the body.

**How Should I Take Brigatinib?**

*   Brigatinib comes as a tablet to take by mouth.
*   It is usually taken with or without food once daily.
*   Take brigatinib at around the same time every day.
*   Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand.
*   Take brigatinib exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

**What Special Precautions Should I Follow?**

Before taking brigatinib:

*   Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brigatinib, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in brigatinib tablets. Ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.
*   Tell your doctor and pharmacist what other prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take.

**What Should I Know About Storage and Disposal of This Medication?**

Store brigatinib in its original container at room temperature away from moisture and heat. Do not remove the desiccant packet from the bottle. Keep brigatinib out of reach of children and pets. Dispose of any unused brigatinib tablets responsibly.

**What Should I Do If I Forget a Dose?**

If you forget to take a dose of brigatinib, do not double the dose. Take your next scheduled dose at the usual time. If you vomit after taking brigatinib, do not take another dose. Continue your regular dosing schedule.

**What Side Effects Can This Medication Cause?**

Common side effects of brigatinib include:

*   Fatigue
*   Diarrhea
*   Nausea and vomiting
*   Headache
*   Muscle pain

Less common side effects of brigatinib may include:

*   High blood pressure
*   Slow heartbeat
*   Diabetes or other blood sugar problems
*   Kidney or liver disease

**What Should I Know About Overdose?**

If you take too much brigatinib, call your doctor or pharmacist immediately. Do not attempt to treat an overdose yourself.

**What Other Information Should I Know?**

Brigatinib may interact with other medications, including antifungals, ketoconazole, buprenorphine and naloxone (Suboxone), carbamazepine (Equetro, Tegretol, Teril, others), clarithromycin, cyclosporine (Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune), diltiazem (Cardizem, Cartia, Diltzac, others), efavirenz (Sustiva, in Atripla, Symfi), erythromycin (E.E.S., Eryc, Erythrocin), indinavir (Crixivan), nefazodone, nelfinavir (Viracept), nevirapine (Viramune), phenobarbital; phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek), pioglitazone (Actos, in Actoplus Met, Duetact, Oseni), rifabutin (Mycobutin), rifampin (Rifadin, Rimactane, in Rifamate, in Rifater), ritonavir (Norvir, in Kaletra, Technivie, Viekira), sirolimus (Rapamune), tacrolimus (Astagraf, Envarsus, Prograf), or verapamil (Calan, Verelan, in Tarka). Your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects.

**Medication Information**

**Important Warning**

If you are male, you and your female partner should use birth control during your treatment and continue to use birth control for 3 months after your final dose. Brigatinib may harm the fetus.

Tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. You should not breastfeed during your treatment with brigatinib and for up to 1 week after your final dose.

This medication may decrease fertility in men. Talk to your doctor about the risks of taking brigatinib.

**Before Taking Brigatinib**

* Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brigatinib, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in brigatinib tablets.
* Inform your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take.

**Interactions with Other Medications**

* Antifungals such as itraconazole (Onmel, Sporanox, Tolsura), ketoconazole
* Buprenorphine and naloxone (Suboxone)
* Carbamazepine (Equetro, Tegretol, Teril, others)
* Clarithromycin
* Cyclosporine (Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune)
* Diltiazem (Cardizem, Cartia, Diltzac, others)
* Efavirenz (Sustiva, in Atripla, Symfi)
* Erythromycin (E.E.S., Eryc, Erythrocin)
* Indinavir (Crixivan)
* Nefazodone
* Nelfinavir (Viracept)
* Nevirapine (Viramune)
* Phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek)
* Pioglitazone (Actos, in Actoplus Met, Duetact, Oseni)
* Rifabutin (Mycobutin)
* Rifampin (Rifadin, Rimactane, in Rifamate, in Rifater)
* Ritonavir (Norvir, in Kaletra, Technivie, Viekira)
* Sirolimus (Rapamune)
* Tacrolimus (Astagraf, Envarsus, Prograf)
* Verapamil (Calan, Verelan, in Tarka)

**Special Precautions**

* Tell your doctor what herbal products you are taking, especially St. John's wort.
* Inform your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure; a slow heartbeat; diabetes or other blood sugar problems; or kidney or liver disease.

**Dietary Instructions**

Avoid eating grapefruit and drinking grapefruit juice while taking brigatinib.

**Missing a Dose**

* Skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule.
* Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one.
* If you miss taking brigatinib for 14 days or longer, talk to your doctor before starting to take it again. You will probably have to restart taking it at a lower dose.

**Side Effects**

Brigatinib may cause side effects such as:

* Nausea
* Diarrhea
* Vomiting
* Constipation
* Tiredness
* Rash
* Headache
* Numbness, pain, tingling, or burning feeling in the feet or hands
* Back or joint pain
* Loss of appetite
* Difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

* Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
* Chest pain
* Cough with or without mucus
* Fever
* Headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, or feeling faint
* Blurred or double vision
* Seeing flashes of light
* Light hurting your eyes
* Seeing "floaters" or small specks
* Extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness
* Upper stomach pain that may spread to the back or get worse with eating; weight loss; or nausea
* Slow or irregular heartbeat
* Muscle pain, spasms, tenderness, or weakness

Brigatinib may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online (https://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch) or by phone (1-800-332-1088).

**Brigatinib: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Side Effects**

* slow or irregular heartbeat
* muscle pain, spasms, tenderness, or weakness

If you experience any unusual problems while taking brigatinib, call your doctor.

In case of a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the FDA's MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online or by phone.

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in its original container, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

Dispose of unneeded medications safely, using a medicine take-back program or visiting the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website for more information.

**In Case of Emergency/Overdose**

If you overdose on brigatinib, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, is having trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**Other Information**

Keep all appointments with your doctor and laboratory. Your doctor will order lab tests before treatment to see if your cancer can be treated with brigatinib.

Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all medications, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you to each doctor's visit or hospital stay.
